note.body:
After "nautilus -q" it appeared some message about some python-extension.
I've found out the issue was related to an old "nautilus-terminal" python extension.
Since the extension wasn't installed with apt or pip, i ran the following commands:

sudo rm -r /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nautilus_terminal*
sudo rm -r /usr/local/share/nautilus-python/extensions/

(note that under "usr/local/share/nautilus-python/extensions/" there was only a nautilus-terminal file)

The issue then ceased to exist.

After that, I could go to dconf-edit and go to:
"org > flozz > nautilus-terminal" and "erase the key" since no schema was available.

events.target_title: Adding Additional VPN Breaks First VPN

note.body:
As mentioned in the upstream bug report, i think it is an issue with a stray PSK file that didn't get deleted :
*  https://github.com/nm-l2tp/NetworkManager-l2tp/issues/112

Doing `sudo rm /etc/NetworkManager/system-connections/*` probably worked because when a new VPN connection was created, the new PSK file which contains a UUID (i.e. `/etc/ipsec.d/nm-l2tp-ipsec-UUID.secrets`) had a UUID that came alphabetically after the problematic one, so was the one that was used for the VPN connection with strongswan.

I believe this issue has been fixed with NetworkManager-l2tp 1.2.12 and later.

events.target_title: After applying settings in Displays module, the behaviors of "Keep changes" and "Revert settings" are swapped

note.body:
Another user with a XPS 9575 here, suffering from the same issue. Maybe I can add some relevant information:
* The issue is still present on Gnome 3.34.1.
* The effect of the dc=0 parameter is subject to the UEFI version. Before performing an update from version 1.2.1, setting the parameter prevented the issue to appear. After updating to version 1.7.1, the switch did not have an effect anymore.
* The monitor configuration is now also reset if the screen gets locked: This makes the bug even more annoying now, since I have to reconfigure the screens around 10-20 times a day (no exaggeration ;) ). I'm not sure what could have caused this. I cannot remember that this behavior occurred prior to 3.34.0.
* Most important: Triggering a GPU reset manually via the sysfs entry of the AMD card also causes a revert of the monitor configuration, i.e. the initial one before selecting "Revert changes" to obtain the desired monitor configuration. The command to trigger a GPU reset of the AMD card is `echo "1" > /sys/bus/pci/devices/0000\:01\:00.0/reset`. IMO, this proves that the GPU reset or something along that code path causes the problems we are observing.

Overall, this bug seems like the result of some "almost bugs" in the amdgpu driver and the wayland counterpart in mutter.

Since only XPS 9575 owners seem to be affected by the issue (please correct me if I'm wrong) and it is obviously coupled with the hybrid graphics setup, we might also consider a blacklisting approach for this system in the hybrid graphic support of mutter. Sure, this is not nice, but maybe tolerable due to this being a corner case issue (it seems) and considering the time since the first report. (Unfortunately, I'm not familiar with the mutter code :/)

However, there was recently some activity on the amdgpu reset front both in the kernel and mesa, so it might also be worth two more months (or less) to see if those updates fix the problems.

What do you think?

Best,
Alex

events.target_title: WIP: backends-native: Only add gpus with outputs
After applying settings in Displays module, the behaviors of "Keep changes" and "Revert settings" are swapped

note.body:
In the WIP MR above, I've implemented a one-line fix: Only GPUs that can have outputs are added to the list of available GPUs for mutter.

I am absolutely unsure if this is the correct approach since using a secondary GPU for acceleration tasks is not possible by that anymore. Moreover, the fix addresses only GPUs that are available when loading mutter and thus does not consider hotplugging.

A similar alternative, I could think of would be disabling the support for hybrid GPUs by some env flag. Then, only the primary GPU would be added. However, a cleaner approach would fix the config / reset interaction, but I am not sure if that is feasible as this issue seems to be related to the amdgpu reset behavior.

events.target_title: After applying settings in Displays module, the behaviors of "Keep changes" and "Revert settings" are swapped

note.body:
The issue is gone with a plain mutter package (without the patch above), a 5.5.0-rc1 kernel and a mesa 19.3 package installed. As assumed, the reset fixes for polaris-based devices (refs BACO) resolve this issue. With this setup, there does not occur any flickering when lspci or some similar command is invoked.
Moreover, the rotation behavior is also correct now.

I will now close the MR above.

@jltastet Could you please verify that the issue is resolved for you, too? If so, I guess we can close this issue.

Recent Versions of GLib Break Dolphin File-Manager's Thumbnailing when Using 'gtk2' Style
Recent Versions of GLib Break Dolphin File-Manager's Thumbnailing when Using 'gtk2' Style

note.body:
Hi, Emmanuele Bassi. My process was that I replaced (using 'downgrade') with previous known working versions any package that I thought might be connected to Dolphin's thumbnailing or its theming (including Dolphin itself), yet nothing had any effect. Then I thought to start Dolphin in a 'uxterm' in order to see the output. That's when I saw that GLib was outputting errors that were causing '/usr/lib/qt/plugins/kf5/kio/thumbnail.so' to crash. Upon seeing that, when I replaced the GLib package as related in my above originating post, thumbnailing worked.

What I take the GLib error messages (involving 'platform_get_argv0' in the output) to mean is that GLib doesn't recognize the platform "gtk2", and that then causes 'thumbnail.so' to crash. Thus, in order for 'thumbnail.so' to work, apparently it requires GLib not to exit with error messages like that upon not recognizing the platform.

I here provide three PNGs of 'uxterm' output when Dolphin is started in it. 'Dolphin-thumbnailing-working-Windows-style-via-qt5ct.png' is when the 'qt5ct' program is set on the "Windows" style, and thumbnailing works. 'Dolphin-thumbnailing-failing-gtk2-style-via-qt5ct.png' is when the 'qt5ct' program is set on the "gtk2" style, and thumbnailing doesn't work. 'Dolphin-thumbnailing-failing-gtk2-style-direct.png' is when QT_QPA_PLATFORMTHEME= is directly set on "gtk2", and thumbnailing doesn't work.

![Dolphin-thumbnailing-working-Windows-style-via-qt5ct](/uploads/2400f9ae4803671bd8a9cb324ba53bf6/Dolphin-thumbnailing-working-Windows-style-via-qt5ct.png)

![Dolphin-thumbnailing-failing-gtk2-style-via-qt5ct](/uploads/a8d6569947019827c7cf3a0af247295d/Dolphin-thumbnailing-failing-gtk2-style-via-qt5ct.png)

![Dolphin-thumbnailing-failing-gtk2-style-direct](/uploads/c693314bc161f84cf4b893c55372327d/Dolphin-thumbnailing-failing-gtk2-style-direct.png)

Whether the style is set via the 'qt5ct' program or is directly set with QT_QPA_PLATFORMTHEME= doesn't matter to this problem. If "gtk2" is the style, thumbnailing fails either way, yet every other style works.

Regarding your question, "What does QtPlatform define as ‘gtk2’?" At this moment I don't know how to parse that, and so at this moment I do not know the answer to this question.

I hope the above information is helpful in fixing this problem. Thank you for your time!

events.target_title: Printing to a file cannot write outside the Flatpak sandbox

note.body:
Just wanted to add something I noticed about this bug in case it's useful. When printing an email the print dialog does not show the CUPS print queues available on the host system. Additionally print-to-file is  not able to access outside the sandbox to the users /home file system to output print jobs. 

However running with --filesystem=home option allows print-to-file to work, which at least gives a workaround for https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=192748 if /home filesystem access can be enabled by default in the flatpak. 
 
flatpak run --filesystem=home  org.gnome.Evolution

Tested on Evolution Version  3.34.1 (by Flathub.org) on Fedora workstation 30.

events.target_title: Create new file

note.body:
It is about having a quick way to create a simple file of a flexible type, the way Windows does it. There can be many practical files that do not arise from a more functional application. Say, someone wants to type down a quick shell script. For now, one has to get to some text editor and then save it as a .sh file, or worse still open the terminal. If a simple create file option was available in the left click drop down menu, there would be a few 'net click savings', compared to the status quo.

'Taps (Clicks) you could be spending with your children:- Stephen Colbert (Yo app)'

events.target_title: Create new file

note.body:
Hi, 

Windows, if I remember correctly, allows one the option of creating just new text files, through the right click select option. I think that in Linux, because of the flexibility with the file extensions, it would be possible to give users the option of creating a more diverse set of files.

With the shell script example what I had in mind was this- you allow the user to click-create a new generic file. In windows, as soon as the file is created, the user is given the option to rename the file (text file). In Linux, I guess we can allow for a very similar option to not just rename but even specify the extension. So as soon as the user finishes renaming, he or she get a file that can be clicked to open with the default application/IDE/player. Nautilus already allows one to create a new folder. Statistically, I feel there would be more demand for creating new files. 

'Taps you could be spending with your children'. That was a comedy line used by Stephen Colbert in explaining an app named Yoapp that could send just one message, and claimed to eliminate many clicks compared to other messaging apps. I feel that a simple choice of creating a new file through a left click could be less expensive in terms of clicks and mouse movements for the average desktop user.

Cheers :)

Job

note.body:
Here's a profile of gnome-shell while it's hung responding to a stream of keystrokes from two keyboards:
![gnome-shell-1858-profile](/uploads/b931aeb4671e1648c3e9c7cbd2966464/gnome-shell-1858-profile.png)

`reload_keybindings` is part of `mutter`.

events.target_title: MappingNotify event freezes drawing windows in Gnome for ~100ms

note.body:
In mutter/src/core/keybindings.c, reload_keybindings() is hooked directly to the `keymap-changed` signal.
In mutter/src/backends/x11/meta-backend-x11.c, the `keymap-changed` signal is emitted on every `XkbMapNotify` X event.

I see `MappingNotify` events in xev preceding any keystroke typed on a different keyboard than the previous keystroke.  I see this with or without Gnome running, so Gnome is not causing these events, it is just responding poorly to them.

note.body: Firefox seems to default to using wayland only when inside gnome, when using swaywm, it would start with X11. I used this to force wayland when inside sway. Sorry, I should have been more clear from the start. In hindsight, this seems like user error on my part and is probably not a bug.

events.target_title: Large number of routes installed into kernel cause high cpu usage
GNOME Wayland has stuttery mouse movement and lag with Minecraft
GIMP IOS?
GIMP IOS?

note.body:
Yes and no.
At first I was happy to see GIMP on IOS.  
I have been waiting for an IOS version for mobile phones to come out and would gladly pay for it.  
Then I downloaded them and it didn’t feel like Gimp.. honestly I was worried if it was GIMP, that my question would be insulting because I appreciate the free software and didn’t want to come across rude.  
well I know that gimp is a free software and a lot of liberties are allowed, but this is just very deceiving.  And quite frankly, the apps are an insult to GIMP developers and staff.  Gimp would never put out a gray screen with loaded with advertisements.  People like myself are well aware you all rely on donations and I do donate when I can (probably more often than most people).

events.target_title: GIMP IOS?

note.body:
Hi. Sorry for my late reply.  
Yes and No. 
I def thought it was GIMP before downloading.  I understand that you all are generous with your software but I don’t think that would mean someone can use your name to make money off of it because the app also is loaded with tons of advertisements. 
While I understand free apps on the market are funded by ads.. these apps had more ads than your usual. Red Flag One.  
After I got passed the ads.. honestly the apps are useless.  You literally can’t do anything with them.  Red Flag #2998 I suggest you download them to see yourself, it’s really an insult to GIMP.  

I understand that things are often released when they’re not ready but this just didn’t have Gimp’s quality and effort.  I was afraid of offending GIMP to be honest by even questioning because I appreciate what you all do.  

If I had to pick a yes or no? I would say that, YES, using GIMP’s logo and name was very misleading to convince me to download not one but two useless apps.  And a bummer.  I was so happy to see GIMP on IOS. I should have known better than to even give it a download without searching for a news release.

ETA: The X GIMP app.  Notice is makes it seem like it’s actually gimp and you can edit photos? You can’t.  It’s just a gray screen and a bunch of ads.

note.body:
Thanks for looking at it. I'm open for better solutions.

You are true. It really assumes ```long int``` to be size of pointer.

But the ```value``` needs to stay ```glong``` so that ```return (guchar *)(value + 1);``` works as expected (plus 8 bytes on 64 bit system).

So should I just change two occurrence of:

```gsize len = length + sizeof (gint);```

to

```gsize len = length + sizeof (gint *);```

?

note.body:
Gnome v3.34.1 in manjaro

I am very happy about that I finally found an gnome-shell-extension to disable osk FOREVER. This is the link: https://extensions.gnome.org/extension/1326/block-caribou/

I unzipped it, modified the metadata.json altering `shell-version` to 3.34.1(is is necessary?) and use `gnome-extensions pack` and `gnome-extensions install`(available since gnome v3.34) to install, and after a reboot and enabling this ext in gnome-tweak I get rid of osk.

events.target_title: Gnome user settings : change password frozen

note.body:
Tests results :
- no issue when entering the right current password
- issue when entering the wrong current password
I could reproduce both cases 3 times each with the same result.
So it seems that this is the [](https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1763525) issue.

Now I have a lightly different behavior that the one indicated in Red Hat bugzilla : It says "Actual results: the entire system freezes". On my computer, I have a freeze on Gnome Control Center but all other parts of the desktop are working fine (panel, dock, activities overview, workspaces, launch applications like Files or Gnome Terminal). I only have to kill GCC process to go back to normal.

I also had a problem with finding how to export public, armored key. It is still possible in 3.32.2:

events.target_title: Encrypt local storage
Add a volume slider
Add a volume slider

note.body:
Well yeah its not a bug, this is a feature request.
You need volume control if you want music playing in the background, for example when I'm on a video call, or when I'm playing a game. I might prioritize the playback volume of those other applications more than the music I'm currently listening to.

If you have to type the listed commands every time you want to reprioritize how present you want your music to be, it gets very tedious very fast.

The bugzilla you linked had some terrible arguments i.E. "I don't need this feature so nobody would need this feature!"

There's a reason why every other music player application has volume control.

events.target_title: Add a volume slider

note.body:
Spotify has its own volume control, which directly adjusts its sink-input volume in Pulseaudio.

You can use Pulseaudio to adjust the spotify slider and spotify to adjust the sink-input volume for Spotify. I don't see how this would cause confusion.

Edit3: I recorded a video of this, to show how this redundancy can hardly cause confusion: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cIJuAKWQHaA

Ironically in previewing the recording I noticed that Gnome Videos does indeed have its own volume slider.

iirc so do VLC and mpd (tho the mpd volume control obviously isn't a slider).

It is however bothersome that one application cannot even adjust it's own audio output and I need to open a separate application for that.

Especially if I need to adjust volumes more frequently, but don't want to waste lots of screen real estate to keep pavucontrol open at all times.

Edit 2: I get that people don't want Gnome to go the way of Systemd "But Lennart, we don't want ease of use and logical grouping of functions, we want *✨the unix way✨*"
But isn't Gnome already headed down that path anyway?

note.body: This is also happening to me with the same versions of Mutter and Fedora, although it has happened since Fedora 30. It most commonly appears after waking from suspend, although it has also happened when waking from just a screen lock and even a few times immediately after logging in. At times the duplicate cursor will appear the same as the real cursor (albeit rotated 90°) but often it remains in the same state. This hasn't happened on Fedora 31/Mutter 3.34 at all, but on F30 it would occasionally appear as what appears to be random, semi-transparent buffer data. See [this image](/uploads/c8543657393729958987cb68f13e7a1e/image.png). I've also noticed that the duplicate cursor will appear even when switching to a different VT, and even on the Plymouth shutdown screen. This is on a system with a Radeon RX 580, and I've always used Wayland due to performance issues I experienced with Xorg.

note.body:
> What I would love to see, though, is a thin wrapper that mangles the terminal traffic (in both directions) according to a flexible configuration file. This would reside between the terminal emulator and the shell (or other app) it launches. According to its configuration file, it could filter out the sequence that enables mouse support, or do whatever else. This utility would then be equally useful for users of all various terminal emulators, not just GNOME Terminal or VTE-based ones. Someone needs to step up, write and maintain it in great quality and also "advertise" it to become popular enough that eventually distributions start shipping it. luit(1) and script(1) might be good starting points.

This really requires a full VT100 parser in between the application and terminal(s)/multiplexer(s).  [I've written a utility called LCXterm](https://gitlab.com/klamonte/lcxterm) that, when used in "passthru mode" does some of these things.  In my case it is used to add features -- GPM to X10 mouse conversion, zmodem/kermit downloads, session capture -- rather than remove them.  But it would be an easy-to-medium task to turn it into a real VT100 mangler with things like color conversion and feature filtering.  When in "not-passthru" mode, LCXterm itself runs via ncurses, so it can even become a VT100/Xterm-to-something-else converter.

events.target_title: DECDWL/DECDHL (double width/height) support

note.body:
For a counterpoint, I implemented DECDWL/DECDHL in a [curses-based terminal](https://github.com/klamonte/qodem) circa 2004 as this:

* A per-line flag for double-width/double-height value.
* If the line is either double-width or double-height, on the rendering loop draw each glyph as "glyph {space}", and wrapping as normal on the right margin.

I'm guessing the above design was done by a lot of 80's/90's-era terminals, given that the ["vttest score card"](http://www.columbia.edu/kermit/k95vtk95.html) popularized by Kermit had an entry for "[ ] 104. True double-high/wide lines, not simulated" .  But either way, it does lead to a VT100 parser that is functionally complete even if it does not actually put the same glyphs on screen that hardware terminal would do.  The resulting screen would look like this:

![dechdl_1](/uploads/6baecade1fe6aa337d8ff3841ce481f9/dechdl_1.png)

Obviously this isn't ideal, but it does have the nice property that it could easily be used with tmux right now.  And if tmux gained glyph scaling (possibly something like [alacritmux](https://github.com/da-x/alacritmux)) then it would be a small increment from there.

Later on I a developed a trick to expose these sequences to my host terminal if TERM=xterm, as seen [here](http://qodem.sourceforge.net/screens/vttest_4_1.png).  This obviously will not work inside tmux.

> Xterm only implementing it for bitmap fonts and not for nice ones (why?).

If I recall right, xterm has different code paths for rendering via xft/freetype, and I think it does something like a) draw stretched glyph, b) cache it, and it seemed like the truetype code path was a bit more complicated.  PDcurses' X11 backend has a similar limitation: only bitmap fonts at all, so I'm not too surprised that xterm didn't bother closing this gap.  When I implemented double-width for Qodem's [PDcurses X11 backend](https://github.com/klamonte/qodem/blob/0b95200f30efb4e29f646b9df1dd770b46ddd3c2/lib/pdcurses/x11/x11.c#L686), I had to cache the generated double-width/height glyphs or else performance was a dog.

Also: at that time I asked around, and someone with a hardware terminal told me that the upper half of a double-height line does _not_ draw an underline for text that had underline on.  So one can set underline on both rows of a double-height line pair and see a single underline on the bottom row, which is nice (less to worry about).

> a *good* image protocol

Should that image protocol ever arise (sigh...), then double-width/height could be supported the way Jexer does:

* Same per-line flag for double-width/double-height value as above.
* When the line is either double-width or double-height, on the rendering loop draw each glyph as a double-width image.
* Double-width glyphs (this also applies to CJK/emoji) are tracked as paired cells on the screen (right and left halves), so that when the mouse selects/hovers, or the cursor box/underline is drawn, it spans both cells.

[Result here.](https://jexer.sourceforge.io/screenshots/jexer_sixel_in_sixel.png)

This solution _would_ be compatible with tmux, IF an image protocol is ever settled on that tmux can handle.

events.target_title: Add option to disable mouse handling in gnome-terminal

note.body:
> > GPM to X10 mouse conversion

> Instead of this, GPM + the kernel should be changed to report xterm-compatible events straight away: [GPM #29](https://github.com/telmich/gpm/issues/29). Seems reasonably doable, and would have a multiple magnitudes bigger impact.

Thank you for the pointer, I've put a comment there for those looking for the feature in the future.

I find it extremely unlikely that kernel + gpm + ncurses would change to support X10 mouse with TERM=linux .  There was/is already the ncurses+libgpm fiasco (in the early 00's one of the distros shipped ncurses with a bad libgpm; today ncurses and libgpm have circular configure dependencies), and 'mc' in particular had an awful bug when you tried to run it an X11 terminal with TERM=linux where it kept spamming the error log trying to use libgpm.

events.target_title: DECDWL/DECDHL (double width/height) support

note.body:
> > A per-line flag

> Does your terminal rewrap the contents on resize?

Nope.

The first terminal I saw with line wrapping/reflow behavior was [Terminator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terminator_%28terminal_emulator%29) (the Java one).  It appears they ended up sacrificing reflow for horizontal scrolling instead.

> I'm glad you mentioned this. As I said, I hardly care about the 80's, 90's. I care about the 2010's, 2020's, and ideally even further ahead in time.

My focus was faithful VT100/VT220, so I passed most of the tests that people ignore such as VT52 submode, double-width/height, selective erase, VT220 character sets, etc.  When I got to supporting "xterm", it was to first cover the terminfo/ncurses case, and then to give me sufficient support for Jexer.

> > Should that image protocol ever arise (sigh...), then double-width/height could be supported the way Jexer does

> Never heard of Jexer. But I'm trying to understand what you mean...

Sorry, thought you might have seen it from the freedesktop image protocol thread.  [Here is Jexer.](https://gitlab.com/klamonte/jexer)

Jexer's primary project goal is to expose what "xterm" can really do: anyevent mouse tracking, draggable/resizable windows, UTF8, and so forth.  When people first migrated out of DOS, the X11 terminals had a lot of cruft (as you well know).  Multiple incompatible character sets/encoding and X10 mouse support that broke UTF8 encoding were two big ones.  It wasn't until 2006-ish that the distros finally started using primarily UTF8 for LANG, and 2012 for SGR mouse encoding to land in xterm.  In 2013 when I realized that stock xterm could finally correctly support Turbo Vision like applications, I started writing Jexer's ancestor project in D, called d-tui.

> (No, most definitely there shouldn't be, because it would necessarily break existing great features that we have, such as being able to change the font size, or to have a detached tmux – but let's leave this discussion for another time and another place.)

That discussion is happening already [here](https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/terminal-wg/specifications/issues/12) .  There are lots of competing ideas floating around, but long story short: users want images in their terminals, and are more than willing to break every "correct" design idea/assumption that a terminal author has in order to get them.  Case in point, they are willing to use w3m-img -- which has hacks for common terminals to locate their drawing surface -- in order to splat a bitmap directly on top of that surface, completely ignoring everything about the character cell metaphor:  this is every "'ranger' doesn't show thumbnails in my favorite terminal!" issue out there.

And if you have images, then you also have insane people developing "full GUI" features to run inside your terminal.  "Thumbnails in 'ranger' that work over ssh" pretty much immediately becomes custom fonts (CJK/emoji/powerline) at any font size, and if one of those people builds a terminal widget then that widget can also get VT100 double-width/height.

> Apart from being an insane design to begin with, there are tons of further technical problems.

These are weighty questions, and we will be stuck with them one way or the other because DEC already made sixel and people really want their thumbnails in 'ranger'.  I won't even pretend to have the answers, just the ability with Jexer (IMHO basically a niche research project) to show people what those ideas can concretely look and behave like.  I'm just a guy who prefers to say, "Let's code it up and see how hard it really is first", and then being informed enough to say, "We're not doing it not because we can't, but because we shouldn't."  I hope that in the end I provide more help than frustration to others reaching their decisions on features.

(The users have always surprised me in what they prioritize.  It took a good decade after the fact for me to see that they really just don't care about vttest compliance so long as ncurses works OK, but by gosh they really need their fullwidth multi-codepoint emojis.)

In this particular case, VTE is probably best served by noting that double-width/double-height sequences are detected and deliberately stripped out, because reflowable text is more important.

Test *alpha_symmetric_transform* fails on AMD Zen (Ryzen, EPYC) system built with GCC

note.body:
I have no idea, what babl is about, just had a quick look at the source and ran the test program. It seems to me, that babl picks an algorithm from a number of alternative implementations based on timing. Also it looks like some result deviations are explicitly tolerated. There's a debug option for it: BABL_DEBUG_CONVERSIONS.

```
buczek@theinternet:~$ grep "model name" /proc/cpuinfo |head -1
model name	: Intel(R) Xeon(R) CPU E5-1650 v3 @ 3.50GHz
buczek@theinternet:~$ BABL_DEBUG_CONVERSIONS=1 LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/scratch/tmp/babl-build BABL_PATH=/scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions /scratch/tmp/babl-build/tests/alpha_symmetric_transform
/scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions/sse2-float.so 0: RGBA float to RaGaBaA float  error:0.000000 cost:71.000000  
/scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions/gegl-fixups.so 0: RGBA float to RaGaBaA float  error:0.000000 cost:76.000000  
/scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions/sse2-float.so 0: RaGaBaA float to RGBA float  error:0.000000 cost:101.000000  
/scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions/sse2-float.so 1: RaGaBaA float to RGBA float  error:0.004140 cost:100.000000  
/scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions/gegl-fixups.so 0: RaGaBaA float to RGBA float  error:0.000000 cost:81.000000  
```
So for Intel, "RaGaBaA float to RGBA float" is won by "gegl-fixups.so 0" with the lowest cost of 81. This algorithm is shown with "error:0.000000".

Amd:
```
buczek@elcattivo:~$ grep "model name" /proc/cpuinfo |head -1
model name	: AMD EPYC 7601 32-Core Processor
buczek@elcattivo:~$ BABL_DEBUG_CONVERSIONS=1 LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/scratch/tmp/babl-build BABL_PATH=/scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions /scratch/tmp/babl-build/tests/alpha_symmetric_transform
/scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions/sse2-float.so 0: RGBA float to RaGaBaA float  error:0.000000 cost:81.000000  
/scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions/gegl-fixups.so 0: RGBA float to RaGaBaA float  error:0.000000 cost:65.000000  
/scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions/sse2-float.so 0: RaGaBaA float to RGBA float  error:0.000000 cost:116.000000  
/scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions/sse2-float.so 1: RaGaBaA float to RGBA float  error:0.004140 cost:79.000000  
/scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions/gegl-fixups.so 0: RaGaBaA float to RGBA float  error:0.000000 cost:83.000000  
../babl/babl-internal.h:214 babl_log()
	separate alpha 10.2: 100000.007812500!=100000.000000000(ref)  
../babl/babl-internal.h:214 babl_log()
	separate alpha 11.1: 49999.996093750!=50000.000000000(ref)  
../babl/babl-internal.h:214 babl_log()
	separate alpha 11.2: 499999.968750000!=500000.000000000(ref)  

../babl/babl-internal.h:214 babl_log()
	associatd-alpha 10.2: 100000.007812500!=100000.000000000(ref)  
../babl/babl-internal.h:214 babl_log()
	associatd-alpha 11.1: 49999.992187500!=50000.000000000(ref)  
../babl/babl-internal.h:214 babl_log()
	associatd-alpha 11.2: 499999.937500000!=500000.000000000(ref)  
```
For AMD, "RaGaBaA float to RGBA float" is won by "sse2-float.so 1" with the lowest cost of 79. This algorithm is shown with "error:0.004140".

Of course, on a loaded system the timing might be different and there might be another implementation selected as on a idle system. To make things even more complicated, the software might be doing some caching of the timing test. I found

```
buczek@theinternet:~$ cat /scratch/local/buczek/.cache/babl/babl-fishes 
#BABL_0_1_70-32-ga03dd58 BABL_PATH_LENGTH=3 BABL_TOLERANCE=0.000005
RGBA float
RaGaBaA float
	pixels=0 cost=71 error=0.000000
	/scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions/sse2-float.so 0: RGBA float to RaGaBaA float
----
RaGaBaA float
RGBA float
	pixels=0 cost=81 error=0.000000
	/scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions/gegl-fixups.so 0: RaGaBaA float to RGBA float
----
```
So maybe, all of this randomness is "expected behavior" of the library and the test should just tolerate the same error level as the selection algorithm does?

events.target_title: Test *alpha_symmetric_transform* fails on AMD Zen (Ryzen, EPYC) system built with GCC

note.body:
Its called "Runtime profiling/validating and code-path optimizing with persistence of profiling data across runs, with caching of results." [http://gegl.org/babl/]

Not exactly what you want if you are looking for reproducible results.

The three competing algorithms for `RaGaBaA float to RGBA float` are:

* [`conv_rgbAF_rgbaF`](extensions/gegl-fixups.c#L451)
* [`conv_rgbAF_linear_rgbaF_linear_shuffle`](extensions/sse2-float.c#L111)
* [`conv_rgbAF_linear_rgbaF_linear_spin`](extensions/sse2-float.c#L175)

When `BABL_TOLERANCE=0` is specified via environment, the test succeeds on EPYC, too:

    buczek@elcattivo:~$ sh -v run.sh
    #! /bin/bash
    grep "model name" /proc/cpuinfo |head -1
    model name	: AMD EPYC 7601 32-Core Processor
    rm -rf /scratch/local/buczek/.cache/babl
    BABL_TOLERANCE=0 \
    BABL_DEBUG_CONVERSIONS=1  \
    LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/scratch/tmp/babl-build BABL_PATH=/scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions /scratch/tmp/babl-build/tests/alpha_symmetric_transform
    /scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions/sse2-float.so 0: RGBA float to RaGaBaA float  error:0.000000 cost:88.000000  
    /scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions/gegl-fixups.so 0: RGBA float to RaGaBaA float  error:0.000000 cost:62.000000  
    /scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions/sse2-float.so 0: RaGaBaA float to RGBA float  error:0.000000 cost:94.000000  
    /scratch/tmp/babl-build/extensions/sse2-float.so 1: RaGaBaA float to RGBA float  error:0.004140 cost:75.000000  

For some reason, `gegl-fixups.so 0: RaGaBaA float to RGBA float` disappears from the output when `BABL_TOLERANCE=0` is used. Didn't try to figure out, why.

events.target_title: Test *alpha_symmetric_transform* fails on AMD Zen (Ryzen, EPYC) system built with GCC

note.body:
The problem is, that [alpha_symmetric_transform.c](tests/alpha_symmetric_transform.c) specifies the tolerance as an absolute value (`#define TOLERANCE 0.001`). This fails on the big numbers in the test array ( 49999.996 != 50000.0 , 100000.0078 != 100000.0 , 499999.9687 != 500000.0 ) only.

Maybe the tolerance would better be a relative value based on the floating point precision.

events.target_title: Test *alpha_symmetric_transform* fails on AMD Zen (Ryzen, EPYC) system built with GCC

note.body: Maybe I've been on the wrong track. The results of `conv_rgbAF_rgbaF` differ on Intel and AMD, but only when compiled with optimization. `conv_rgbAF_rgbaF` seems to be the algorithm with deviation, which would explain, why it disappears with `BABL_TOLERANCE=0`, although output of `BABL_DEBUG_CONVERSIONS=1` suggests otherwise.

events.target_title: Test *alpha_symmetric_transform* fails on AMD Zen (Ryzen, EPYC) system built with GCC

note.body: The deviation `conv_rgbAF_rgbaF` between Intel and AMD only happens only with `-O3 -funsafe-math-optimizations -ffinite-math-only`, which are implied by `-Ofast` in `meson.build`. I've reduced it a lot already and included the two functions in a separate test program which also shows the different behavior between Intel and ADM. It only happens, when (my copy of) `babl_epsilon_for_zero_float` is inlined into (my copy of) `conv_rgbAF_rgbaF`. It is difficult to reduce this further (and make the test case independent of babl), because most even small changes make the problem disappear.

events.target_title: Test *alpha_symmetric_transform* fails on AMD Zen (Ryzen, EPYC) system built with GCC
Test *alpha_symmetric_transform* fails on AMD Zen (Ryzen, EPYC) system built with GCC

note.body:
It seems to boil down to:

* The exact result of the `rcpss` (approximated reciprocal) instruction is not defined in the x86 architecture. "The maximum error is less than or equal to 1.5*2^-12 times the true reciprocal". Different hardware implementation are allowed to produce different results. 

* babl uses `-Ofast` in `meson.build` which implies `-ffast-math`. This allows gcc to replace divisions with the multiplication of the reciprocal generated by the `rcpps` instruction. Gcc adds an additional step after the instruction to further increase the precision, but still the result may vary on different hardware platforms.

* The failing test uses an *absolute* deviation tolerance of 0.001 for input/output values up to 500000. This alone is above the resolution of a float even without added error by computation and approximation. So the test very much relies on rounding behavior. 

This should be solvable by changing the test to check for relative deviation. Perhaps with something as [0001-p.patch](/uploads/0b2bb7d81f593f8d52a470e6b91e4040/0001-p.patch)

Works on EPYC for me.

events.target_title: Test *alpha_symmetric_transform* fails on AMD Zen (Ryzen, EPYC) system built with GCC

note.body:
If all hardware platforms are to generate the exact same output (good!), perhaps it would be better to change the compiler flags. Currently the compiler is explicitly allowed to trade hardware independence for speed and that is what happens. And this can happen in any code path not just those inside the algorithms which may or may not be cut of by some testing. I'd suggest

- either remove `-Ofast`
- or (less safe) add `-fno-fast-math` behind it
- or (less safe) add `-fno-unsafe-math-optimizations` behind it
- or (less safe) add `-mno-recip` behind it.

Btw: The approximation seen on Intel is in no way more correct than the approximation seen on Epyc. The approximations have about the same precision, both don't match IEEE rules and both don't promise to be stable from model to model.

I've tested plain divs (IEEE correct "gcc_div") , rcpps based divs ("rcpps") and divs with rcpps and the additional Newton-Raphson step (what gcc produces with -Ofast "gcc_rcpps") against the IEEE-correct result of a double precision divide and searched for worst cases. These are:

Intel:

    max gcc_div error   : 1/3.401162134214653e+38   = 2.940171507674700e-39
                                          gcc_div   : 2.940172207981652e-39
    rel error: 2.381857484856642e-07

    max gcc_rcpps error : 1/4.143762972344320e+14   = 2.413265446585748e-15
                                          gcc_rcpps : 2.413265052879756e-15
    rel error: 1.631424311403513e-07

    max rcpps error     : 1/9.484580815242265e+18   = 1.054342853395210e-19
                                          rcpps     : 1.054026623739570e-19
    rel error: 2.999305725098155e-04

 Epyc:
 
    max gcc_div error   : 1/3.401162134214653e+38   = 2.940171507674700e-39
                                          gcc_div   : 2.940172207981652e-39
    rel error: 2.381857484856642e-07

    max gcc_rcpps error : 1/1.204898580908775e-04   = 8.299453712077295e+03
                                          gcc_rcpps : 8.299452148437500e+03
    rel error: 1.884027369767691e-07

    max rcpps error     : 1/1.204905565828085e-04   = 8.299405599581065e+03
                                          rcpps     : 8.302000000000000e+03
    rel error: 3.126007504761543e-04

events.target_title: Test *alpha_symmetric_transform* fails on AMD Zen (Ryzen, EPYC) system built with GCC

note.body:
> Can somone confirm that the test passes on epyc now?

Sorry, it does not, because the problematic rcpps-instruction is generated for extensions/gegl-fixups.c . If you do 

```
diff --git a/extensions/meson.build b/extensions/meson.build
index acfbbcb..ea57428 100644
--- a/extensions/meson.build
+++ b/extensions/meson.build
@@ -29,7 +29,7 @@ extensions = [
   ['fast-float', no_cflags],
   ['half', no_cflags],
   ['float', no_cflags],
-  ['gegl-fixups', no_cflags],
+  ['gegl-fixups', '-fno-unsafe-math-optimizations'],
   ['gggl-lies', no_cflags],
   ['gggl-table-lies', no_cflags],
   ['gggl-table', no_cflags],
```

instead (of the last two commits 84128d5 and e41da81), the tests pass on Epyc.

events.target_title: Test *alpha_symmetric_transform* fails on AMD Zen (Ryzen, EPYC) system built with GCC

note.body:
I see.

e41da81 "babl: adjust default BABL_TOLERANCE" would work as expected, but you'd need to reduce the tolerance from 0.0000047 to less then 0.00000001012514205811498785852136118325848845866943293003714643418788909912109375 to cut out the algorithm which fails in the test. Of course, you had no way to find that number without the processor.

However, I don't think, this would be a correct solution.

You said, you want to go to hashes, so you need reproducible math without hardware dependency. For that you'd need to get rid of `-funsafe-math-optimizations` everywhere. If you do that anyway, the problem would be solved already.

Currently, the compiler flags trade away reproducibility over different implementations for speed. If this is to be kept, why not fix the bug in the `alpha_symmetric_transform.c` test? As I wrote above, it expects a precision which is in the magnitude of the floating point precision itself. When we allow the compiler to use optimizations, which may vary from hardware to hardware, at the same time, the result is random. If `alpha_symmetric_transform.c` would keep the required precision sensible, this wouldn't be a problem.

> To me it seems like EPYC has trouble in the value range we care about

You couldn't know, but my test didn't check for that. I searched for the maximum error, but the same error may well be spread all over the range. So the "worst case" is just a random sample from a possible number of equally worst cases.

The precision of the gcc-code using the approximation instruction is in the 10^-7 magnitude on both AMD and Intel.

events.target_title: key events are not reported to accessibility layer any more in gtk4

note.body:
I was just wondering if there were any status updates on this issue.
As a user of Orca on Linux, it brings me a lot of sadness that there is so much push back against accessibility support. I am actually attending school to learn to program, however, the issues discussed here are still too advanced for me to understand with the coding knowledge I have. Although what we have may be a sad hack, it does allow me as well as other individuals to have a job and live productive lives in society. One of my hopes was to actually start working on libreOffice accessibility since I really believe in open standards as I become a more experienced coder, however, if GTK accessibility is broken, this will never be a reality. I also have a huge dream of working on speech recognition on Linux and making it surpass what is available on other platforms, however, if I can't access the desktop, that goal won't be realized for me either. 
If people were not willing to do the work, it would be one thing, however, it deeply pains me to see those in power actively rejecting patches that have been crafted to improve the lives of users now, due to wishes for an improved architecture in the future which is barely even in the planning phase. This is behavior which I have witnessed as recently as this past week in other threads. Its worth considering that every time you push against accessibility, you are literally taking away opportunities and building barriers for others in society who may be free software advocates now or in the future. Quite frankly, it shocks me to witness some of the behavior on this and other threads, especially from those who represent large software companies like IBM. No one is arguing against the fact that accessibility needs to be modernized, right now what we have are a few individuals with full plates doing what they can. We have made some huge gains recently due to the kind folks like martin and jessica at Igalia building ATK into Chromium. It worries me that if GTK accessibility improvements are blocked, it may be such a blow to Linux Accessibility that it could take years to recover.
In the 90's, screen readers were such hacks that they intersepted drawing commands going to the screen, however, if it were not for those, I would not be typing this message right now because I would not know how to type or have the education that I currently do.  I urge those in power to reconsider their positions so that at least the status quo can be preserved. Also consider that you may need assistive technologies some day. None of us are getting younger. Macular degeneration which is a common condition for loss of eyesight is far from being solved with current technology.
It would also be great to see free software make some inroads into large agencies. That goal won't be realized if the desktops like Gnome that are shipped by commercial distributions are not accessible which would really be a shame since free software has so much to offer. I have friends who sign contracts in large agencies and solutions which are not accessible are immediately removed from the running if the vendor cannot promise a timeline for remediation.

Idea:

Create a second exec call to open a file-chooser dialog. 
E.g.: 
 thunar # calls thunar as usual.
 thunar --file-chooser # calls thunar in the form of a file chooser.

- The implementation would then be forwarded to the distro makeer (on mobile: OS/ device maker) => less (redundant) implementation in GTK
- The design would be consistent with the rest of the distro (design consistency)

Implement a minimal fallback version, in case there is no file-chooser implementation on the current system.



@ Idea of making it less feature-like:

note.body:
Just for the records I confirm that this issue is still present in the latest release 2.10.14. Just seems that there is no solution or workaround to solve the problem. I can confirm that this is related to Win7-x86 and **NOT** related to "admin privileges". I will also do tests with Win7-x64 and post back the results.

Strange enough is that whenever I reboot the VM it seems to work until a network drive mapping is added to the machine. After that every attempt to open the preferences dialog crashes the application. The situation can be resolved by removing that network drive mapping or rebooting the machine.

Maybe this is the reason someone else reported that the issue happens only in a managed environment where having network drive mappings (via login script) is quite common.
